Award.AwardTitle: Spatio-temporal regulation of hormonal interactions in Arabidopsis shoot apex: Live imaging and cell type-specific analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The arrangement of leaves along a plant shoot or branch is determined by the manner in which undifferentiated cells in shoot apical meristems (SAMs) cells are allocated to leaf primordia. The arrangement is critical because it determines the plant's light harvesting capability, which in turn influences biomass production. This project aims to understand dynamic processes that control the spatial patterning of leaf development in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. The plant hormones auxin and cytokinin play crucial roles, but while computational models explain the importance of auxin, the function of cytokinin is not well understood. This is because cytokinin regulates several interconnected processes that cannot be easily deciphered by traditional static analytical methods. This project will elucidate the role of cytokinin using transient manipulation of hormone levels and signaling followed by live imaging and high-resolution molecular analysis. It will also explore how auxin and cytokinin influence locally-acting transcription factors implicated in leaf patterning.

The project outcomes will be used to develop predictive computational models to facilitate engineering of crop plants for optimal light harvest and increased productivity. The live images of actively developing shoot apices of plants and dynamic data sets will be used in a new interdisciplinary graduate course on developmental dynamics, and in an undergraduate cell biology course. These data also will be incorporated into a summer workshop for schoolteachers that will introduce them to recent progress in dynamic analysis of developmental systems. The dynamic data sets will be made available through a web portal (http://cybersam.ucr.edu/Plone) for use in research and teaching. The project will also provide training in live imaging, image processing and high-resolution genomics for a postdoctoral fellow, a graduate student and several undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main finding of this activity is that stem cell maintenance in shoot meristems involves a single transcription factor that collectively represses several differentiation-promoting factors and hormonal pathways implicated in differentiation. The collective output excludes differentiation program from stem cells to maintain their pluripotency and proliferative ability throughput the life of a plant.  A multicellular computational model has been developed that integrates cell-cell signaling and gene expression which explains experimental observations and it should act as a testbed for generating new future hypotheses about growth and differentiation of shoot apex in higher plants. In making these discoveries, the project has generated resources and methods that will allow cell type-specific and transient manipulation of plant hormones, and reconstruction of transcriptional networks at single cell type resolution that can be used broadly. The project has provided training to post-doctoral fellow, graduate and undergraduate students in interdisciplinary research involving transient gene manipulation, high-resolution and cell type-specific analysis of transcriptional programs and cell signaling, live imaging, image processing and computational analysis. The project resulted in the development of an outreach program that involved visits to lower income and Latino-dominated schools in Riverside Unified School District and the Alvord Unified School District, who have limited access to research opportunities to educate them about inquiry-based scientific learning techniques used in the laboratory, the process of becoming a scientist and the research being undertaken in PIs and other labs at UCR.
